Natural iron-manganese ores exhibit a good deNOx activity at low temperatures after a simple treatment, but the reason for its low N2 selectivity requires further in-depth study. This work conducted deNOx performance and characterization tests on iron-manganese ore catalysts. Based on the experimental results, a simplified computational model of the iron-manganese ore catalyst (Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface) was constructed, and the density functional theory (DFT) method was used to investigate the mechanism of N2 formation in the NH3-SCR process. Fe and Mn in the iron-manganese ore play an important role in the deNOx activity, and NH3 forms the stable chemical adsorption on its surface, especially on the Fe site, where the adsorption capacity of NH3 is stronger than that of Mn site. The Fe site exhibits better ability than the Mn site in the dehydrogenation reaction of NH3. However, in a comprehensive comparison, the capability of iron-manganese ore catalyst to promote NH3 dehydrogenation is not high. In addition, the key NH2NO intermediate prefers to form on the Mn site over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. Among them, the Mn site is better than the Fe site in promoting the decomposition of NH2NO intermediate to form N2. The study can further understand the microscopic mechanism of iron-manganese ore catalysts in N2 formation, which lays a foundation for improving the N2 selectivity of iron-manganese ore deNOx catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Iron-manganese ore DeNOx DFT N2 selectivity NH2NO Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) mainly come from the burning of waste incineration, steel sintering, and fossil fuels, which can potentially generate acid rain, causing great damage to the environment and even endangering human health and safety in severe cases [1–8]. To achieve efficient removal of NOx, the most widely used NOx removal technology is selective catalytic reduction (SCR), which mainly uses ammonia (NH3) as a reducing agent [9,10]. Before using the technology of SCR for NOx removal, the selection of catalysts is extremely important. In addition, for general industrial emissions such as steel and cement, as the temperature of flue gas is below 230 °C, only the catalyst with low-temperature performance can effectively remove NOx [11,12]. The commercial catalyst widely used at present is a vanadium-based catalyst with excellent deNOx performance [13]. However, in a low-temperature environment, its deNOx performance is not strong and it is toxic [14,15]. The NOx emission standards required by national regulations cannot be met. Urgently, the catalysts with outstanding low-temperature deNOx activity and non-toxic traits should be developed. Low-temperature deNOx catalysts usually consist of transition metals and noble metals [16]. Compounds of transition metals have numerous d-orbital electrons in contrast to noble metal catalysts [17], which can activate reactive gases. Because of its cost-effectiveness and high NOx removal efficiency, it is widely used in deNOx catalysts [18]. The most common transition metals include manganese and iron, etc. [19–21]. Iron oxides exhibit the high resistance to SO₂ [22–24] and manganese oxides possess the excellent redox capabilities. The combination of iron and manganese oxides demonstrates outstanding catalytic performance in the removal of NOx [25,26]. For example, Putluru et al. [27] used co-precipitation and impregnation methods to prepare Mn-Fe/TiO2 and Mn/TiO2 catalysts. The former exhibits superior removal capabilities of NOx in low-temperature environments. This suggests that the introduction of Fe element provides more active sites for the catalyst and compensates for the deficiencies of using Mn element alone. Chen et al. [28] developed a unique hybrid catalyst (consisting of iron and manganese) and witnessed its remarkable capability of deNOx at low temperatures. Shi et al. [29] found that natural ferrous manganese ore demonstrates notable and exceptional NO oxidation capabilities during the process of selective catalytic oxidation (SCO). Schill et al. [30] demonstrated that the mesoporous 30 wt% Mn0.6Fe0.4/TiO2 catalyst is primarily synthesized through a novel hydrothermal approach. They also found that it exhibits good deNOx performance in low-temperature environments. Xu et al. [31] discovered that natural iron-manganese ore (FMO) possesses significant deNOx capabilities at low temperatures. Additionally, FMO contains a large amount of amorphous iron and manganese oxides, and it also exhibits excellent resistance to SO2 poisoning due to its iron content. In comparison to catalysts synthesized in the laboratory containing iron-manganese oxides, natural iron-manganese ore has distinct advantages, such as low cost and direct availability in nature. In NH3-SCR, it shows a good NOx conversion. However, the N2 selectivity of iron-manganese ore catalysts in NH3-SCR is not high, and further research is urgently needed. Density functional theory (DFT) is a highly suitable and effective method for investigating the reaction mechanisms on the catalyst surface [32–35], which can primarily represent micro-atomic level reactions in graphical form, thereby enhancing the visual clarity of the transformation reaction paths between molecules. For instance, Xiang et al. [36] used DFT to explore the adsorption characteristics of reactive gas molecules such as NH3 on the γ-Al2O3 surface and the formation process of various nitrate species. Xie et al. [37] studied the reaction of gases such as NH3 over the surface of γ-Fe2O3 (001) primarily using the DFT method. Gao et al. [38] emphasized that in NH3-SCR, NO activated at Fe sites on the Fe2O3 catalyst reacts with adsorbed NH2 to form the crucial NH2NO intermediate, which subsequently decomposes to produce N2 and H2O. In summary, DFT is the most suitable computational tool for revealing the decomposition mechanisms of gas molecules. This study investigated the deNOx performance and N2 selectivity of iron-manganese ore catalysts and characterized their physicochemical properties. Furthermore, utilizing DFT computational methods, a microscopic atomic-level examination of the N2 selectivity over the iron-manganese ore catalyst surface was conducted. The analysis of NH3 adsorption behavior over the catalyst surface mainly utilized various charge transfer methods. The NH3 dehydrogenation was also studied, where the produced NH2 reacts with activated NO molecules to form the NH2NO intermediate, which is subsequently further converted into N2 and H2O. These conclusions help to develop the iron-manganese ore catalysts with the high deNOx efficiency and N2 selectivity. 2 Experimental and simulation sections 2.1 Experimental section 2.1.1 Sample preparation Four types of iron-manganese ores were used as raw materials for catalyst preparation (all ores were sourced from Guangxi Province) and labeled as the 1-Ore, 2-Ore, 3-Ore, and 4-Ore. Initially, natural iron-manganese ores were ground into granular particles by using a milling machine, and then these particles with the range of 40–60 mesh were separated by using a standard sieve. Subsequently, the samples were placed in a heated air oven and dehydrated at 110 °C for a duration of 13 h, until a stable mass was attained. Ultimately, the dried samples were then calcinated in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 6 h. The resulting calcined particle samples represent the iron-manganese ore catalysts prepared in this study. 2.1.2 Catalyst testing and characterization The activity testing apparatus is shown in Fig. S1. Specific experimental conditions for the catalyst activity testing and the relevant calculation formulas are provided in the supplementary materials. The XRF test utilized a wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (ZSX100e model), with aluminum ring pressing Φ 35 mm, pressure of 20 T/cm3, and the use of a standard database. XRD spectrum test was performed by using the Bruk-erD8 Advance X-ray diffractometer from Bruker Corporation in Germany, with a scanning range from 5° to 90°, step size of 0.02°, and scanning speed of 10 °/min. 2.2 Computational section 2.2.1 Model construction The methods involved in the calculations are provided in the supplementary materials. In this study, E a d s , Δ Q , E B , and E b i n d represent the adsorption energy, Bader charge, reaction energy barrier, and binding energy, respectively, which are obtained by using the Eqs. S(5)-S(8). To meet the convergence requirements, a cutoff energy of 500 eV and a K-point of 4 × 4 × 4 were selected to optimize the β-MnO2 unit cell. The results are seen in Fig. S2. Comparing the optimized parameters (A = B = 4.445 Å, C = 2.937 Å) with the experimental values (A = B = 4.388 Å, C = 2.865 Å), the variation of the error is within 5 %, indicating that the results are reliable and accurate [39]. The crystal cell structure of β-MnO2 is shown in Fig. S3. Previous studies have indicated that the (110) plane of β-MnO2 is the most stable surface, has the highest redox activity, and possesses the lowest low-index surface energy (0.62 J m −2) [40–44]. Hence, for the subsequent electronic and energy calculations, it has been decided to adopt this surface. Based on the optimized unit cell of β-MnO2, a periodic surface model was established in the form of a 4 × 3 supercell. The slab model of β-MnO2 (110) is shown in Fig. S3(b, c). Because the slab model (11.748 Å × 18.858 Å × 21.286 Å) has a large size and the computational resources are limited, the bottom three layers of atoms were fixed, and a 1 × 1 × 1 grid was used to divide the Brillouin zone for the calculation of the adsorption model and electronic properties. A 15 Å vacuum layer was added in the Z-direction. Simultaneously, dipole correction was applied to eliminate the impact of stress. Based on previous results [45–47], we successfully constructed the minimal Fe2O3 molecular cluster, as shown in Fig. S4 and the geometric shape of these Fe2O3 molecular clusters exhibits excellent stability. After optimization, the Fe2O3 molecular clusters in Fig. S4 can be divided into ring-shaped and line-shaped structures. The configuration of Fe2O3 molecular clusters supported over the β-MnO2 (110) surface is depicted in Fig. 1 . The binding of these two types of Fe2O3 molecular clusters on the surface of β-MnO2 (110) is very stable. To more intuitively compare the binding performance of these two types of Fe2O3 molecular clusters on the surface of β-MnO2 (110), we calculated their binding energy and Bader charge, as shown in Fig. 1. The E b i n d (−7.910 eV) of the ring-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters on the surface of β-MnO2 (110) is much smaller than that of the line-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters (−5.079 eV). In addition, the ring-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters ( Δ Q =0.420 e) have a higher amount of acquired charge than the line-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters ( Δ Q =0.198 e). These results indicate that the binding configuration of the ring-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters on the surface of β-MnO2 (110) is more stable. To further clarify their binding strength, we also calculated the electron density variation, and the result is listed in Fig. S5. The number and area of yellow clouds in Fig. S5(a) are both larger than those in Fig. S5(b), which also verifies the conclusion that the amount of electron transfer of the ring-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters is the largest. According to the above results, the binding performance of the ring-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters is significantly better than that of the line-shaped Fe2O3 molecular clusters. Therefore, we choose Fig. 1(a) as the basis for subsequent calculations. In addition, to clearly distinguish Fe atoms in Fe2O3 molecular clusters, we label them as Fe1 and Fe2, and Mn sites on the β-MnO2 (110) surface are labeled as Mn5 and Mn4 sites according to the number of chemical bonds formed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR of iron-manganese ore catalysts The deNOx performance of the four iron-manganese ore catalysts at 80–240 °C are shown in Fig. 2 . Only the NOx conversion of 1-Ore remains above 85 %, even reaching over 98 % at 120–180 °C. However, the low-temperature deNOx activity of 2-Ore and 3-Ore is poor, with the highest NOx conversion of 72 % and 92 % at 120–180 °C, respectively, both lower than the deNOx efficiency of 1-Ore. Especially, the NOx conversion of 4-Ore does not exceed 31 %. This indicates that the deNOx efficiency of 1-Ore is the best. As shown in Fig. 2(b), at 120–180 °C, the N2 selectivity of 1-Ore remains above 75 %, which is higher than that of 2-Ore, 3-Ore, and 4-Ore. Fig. 2(c) shows that the N2O selectivity of 1-Ore at 80–240 °C is lower than that of 2-Ore and 3-Ore. And the N2O selectivity of 4-Ore shows a downward trend in this temperature range, indicating lower N2O selectivity. The ability of iron-manganese ore catalysts to convert NH3 into other species at 80–240 °C shown in Fig. 2(d) is in the order of 1-Ore > 3-Ore > 2-Ore > 4-Ore. In summary, 1-Ore has the best deNOx performance, so it was selected as the model catalyst for further study. 3.2 Characterization results of iron-manganese ore catalysts Table S1 shows the iron-manganese ore contains a significant amount of Mn and Fe elements, which are 35.755 % and 23.153 %, respectively, with a nearly 2:1. Mn and Fe exhibit excellent catalytic performance and thermal stability, providing abundant active sites that is conducive to the adsorption of reactive gases. Additionally, the iron-manganese ore also contains a substantial amount of Si element, accounting for 30.473 %. The XRD result of 1-Ore shown in Fig. 3 shows that it contains a significant amount of SiO2, with distinct diffraction peaks of SiO2 observed at 20.924°, 26.738°, 36.584°, 39.397°, 50.228°, 60.121°, 67.669°, and other positions [48,49]. Simultaneously, distinct diffraction peaks of MnO2 are observed at 28.660°, 37.381°, 56.604°, 68.560°, 72.311°, and 76.015°, with the predominant crystal structure identified as β-MnO2 [50]. Additionally, relatively weak diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 are detected at 35.740°, 43.570°, 57.495°, 62.465°, and 65.934° [51]. However, the intensity of the Fe2O3 diffraction peaks is extremely low, and there is no apparent diffraction peak width. This indicates that Fe2O3 does not exist in a crystalline form but rather in an amorphous cluster structure, loaded on the surface of the catalyst. This finding is consistent with the results reported by Wang et al. [52–54]. Considering that the iron-manganese ore catalyst exhibits the low-temperature SCR performance, with the active elements primarily being transition metals Fe and Mn, in this study, a simplified computational model (Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface) of the iron-manganese ore catalyst was constructed for DFT calculations to investigate its deNOx mechanism. The theoretical computational model is depicted in Fig. 1(a). 3.3 NH3 adsorption over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface In the deNOx process, NH3 first adsorbs on the surface of catalysts and undergoes subsequent catalytic decomposition reactions. NH3 adsorption is one of the key indicators for NOx removal efficiency during the deNOx process [55–57]. NH3 molecules are usually adsorbed on the catalyst surface with the N atom end, forming adsorbed products [58–60]. Fig. 4 illustrates the adsorption configuration of NH3 over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. The Mn and Fe atoms on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface serve as active adsorption sites. NH3 adsorbs on the catalyst surface and forms N-Fe or N-Mn bonds, whose bond lengths are 2.132 Å (N-Fe1 bond), 2.158 Å (N-Fe2 bond), 2.175 Å (N-Mn4 bond), and 2.403 Å (N-Mn5 bond), respectively. The N-Fe1 bond has the smallest bond length, indicating the strongest adsorption of NH3 at the Fe1 site. To validate these results, we calculated the E a d s and Bader charges for NH3. The E a d s values for NH3 at the Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites shown in Fig. 4 are −1.504, −1.134, −1.002, and −0.443 eV, respectively. The smallest E a d s value is at the Fe1 site, indicating a stronger preference for NH3 adsorption at this site. The Δ Q values for the various active sites on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface are −0.138, −0.131, −0.113, and −0.058 e, respectively. After comparing the magnitudes of Δ Q , it is found that NH3 exhibits the largest amount of electron transfer at the Fe1 site, while the smallest amount occurs at the Mn5 site. This suggests that a more pronounced electronic interaction has occurred between the NH3 and the Fe1 atom, with the direction of electron transfer being NH3 → Fe2O3/MnO2 (110). This is one of the reasons that the E a d s is the highest at the Fe1 site on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. To visualize the charge changes of NH3 during adsorption more graphically, the charge density difference of NH3 molecules was also calculated. The results obtained are presented in Fig. S6. The accumulation of substantial cyan clouds in proximity to the NH3 molecule also confirms that the NH3 loses electrons. In summary, NH3 adsorbs on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface and forms the stable chemical adsorption, and it prefers to adsorb over the Fe1 site. To further clarify the binding strength of NH3 over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface, the Partial Density of States (PDOS) and the Crystal Orbital Hamiltonian Population (COHP) of NH3 at the chemical adsorption sites of the catalytic surface were examined, which are shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5 (a, b), (c, d), (e, f), and (g, h) represent the results of PDOS and COHP for NH3 over the catalyst surface at the Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites before and after adsorption, respectively. By analyzing the comparison of PDOS diagrams of NH3 prior to and following its adsorption at Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites, the p-orbitals of N atoms undergo a transition from higher energy levels to lower energy levels. Additionally, the PDOS results show that numerous new hybridization peaks emerge at −7 eV shown in Fig. 5 (b, d) and at −5 eV shown in Fig. 5 (f, h), which suggests a robust interaction between N and Fe/Mn, indicating an intense chemical reaction. The p-orbitals of the N atom and the d-orbitals of the Fe and Mn atoms exhibit a distinct hybridization peak splitting phenomenon near the Fermi level (FL), spreading to higher energy regions, forming numerous bonding and antibonding orbitals, as seen in the COHP results in Fig. 5 (b, d, f, h). At the Fe1 and Fe2 sites, by comparing the COHP diagrams during NH3 adsorption, a significant number of electron pair hybridization peaks, composed of electron pairs with spin-up and spin-down, are clustered about −19, −9, and −7 eV, indicating that at these positions, the hybridization peaks contribute to the most bonding orbitals between N and Fe atoms. In addition, Fig. 5 (b, d) also shows that a portion of spin-up electron pair hybridization peaks form antibonding orbitals at −6 eV and −2.5 eV, located below the FL. They have an inhibitory effect on the binding of NH3 to the catalyst surface. In the -COHP diagrams of NH3 adsorbed at Mn4 and Mn5 sites, a large number of electron pair hybridization peaks are clustered at −18 eV and −4 eV, forming bonding orbitals. This implies that they promote the adsorption and bonding of NH3 on the catalyst surface. In Fig. 5(f), the antibonding orbital at −3 eV is mainly composed of spin-down electron pair hybridization peaks, indicating that spin-down electron pairs have the greatest effect on it. On the other hand, in Fig. 5(h), the antibonding orbital at −2 eV is primarily formed by spin-up electron pair hybridization peaks, which suggests that spin-up electron pairs exert the greatest influence on it. ICOHP (Integrated Crystal Orbital Hamiltonian Population) can be expressed as the summation of the COHP values beneath the topmost occupied electronic state [61–63]. Analyzing the ICOHP values of hybridization peaks with spin-up and spin-down in Fig. 5 (b, d, f, h) (−0.678 > −0.986, −0.456 > −0.868, −0.796 〈 −0.683, −0.242 〉 −0.511), it is noticed that the ICOHP values pertaining to spin-up electron pair hybridization peaks in Fig. 5 (b, d, h) are larger. This indicates that during NH3 adsorption at the Fe1, Fe2, and Mn5 sites, spin-down electrons play the most significant role in promoting the binding of N atoms with Fe and Mn atoms. However, the ICOHP value results in Fig. 5(f) are the opposite, indicating that when NH3 adsorbs at the Mn4 site, spin-up electrons have the greatest effect on promoting the binding of N atoms with Mn atoms. Additionally, beyond the FL, there are numerous electron pairs that significantly contribute to antibonding orbitals. Based on previous research findings [64–66], it has been demonstrated that when reactants adsorb on the surface of transition metals, hybridization peaks proximate to the FL undergo partitioning. Some electrons contribute to the creation of bonding orbitals located below the FL. Another segment, however, contribute to the formation of antibonding orbitals above the FL. Concurrently, as some electrons shift from the positions situated above the FL to those beneath it, the adsorption of NH3 over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface is intensified. This is also one of the reasons for the relatively small E a d s value of NH3 on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the total ICOHP absolute values in Fig. 5 (b, d, f, h) are 1.664, 1.324, 1.476, and 0.753, respectively. Fig. 5(b) has the largest total ICOHP value. This indicates that the formed N-Fe1 bond has the strongest bond strength, corresponding to the conclusion that the E a d s value of NH3 is the smallest at the Fe1 site. However, further research is still required to clarify the mechanism of the decomposition of adsorbed NH3 on the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110). 3.4 NH3 dehydrogenation over the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) The decomposition of NH3 serves as a crucial step because NH3 is unable to directly react with other gaseous reactants. For example, gaseous NO cannot combine with adsorbed NH3 to form an NN bond [37]. Therefore, the dehydrogenation process of NH3 becomes an indispensable step in the subsequent reactions. The catalyst surface possesses numerous unsaturated Lewis acidic sites [67–69], such as exposed Mn and Fe atoms, and they both exhibit electrophilic properties. The lattice oxygen (Oβ) and the adsorbed oxygen (Oα) on the surface of catalysts play a crucial assisting role in the dehydrogenation of NH3 and the formation of species such as NH2 and NH, as well as other intermediates [70–72]. Hence, we explored NH3 dehydrogenation reactions on the Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites over the catalyst surface. In Fig. 6 (a), the NH3 molecule needs to overcome an E B of 1.107 eV to detach one H atom, a process that absorbs 0.208 eV of energy. NH2 is an essential precursor for the formation of the NH2NO species [73–75]. The bond length of the N-Fe1 bond changes from 2.132 → 1.867 Å. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the IS2 → FS2 process overcomes an E B of 1.331 eV. This is an endothermic process, with the N-Fe2 bond length changing from 2.158 → 1.910 → 1.887 Å. Fig. 6(c) illustrates the IS3 → FS3 process, overcoming an E B of 2.050 eV. Among them, the bond length of the N-Mn4 bond changes from 2.175 → 1.977 → 1.899 Å. Fig. 6(d) indicates that the IS4 → FS4 process overcomes an E B of 2.253 eV. Among them, the bond length of the N-Mn5 bond varies from 2.403 → 2.068 → 2.013 Å. From these results, it can be observed that the N-Fe or N-Mn bond lengths formed between NH2 and the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface are significantly reduced, indicating a significant enhancement in the adsorption of NH2 on the catalyst surface after the completion of the NH3 dehydrogenation process. Comparing the energy barriers required to overcome the NH3 dehydrogenation process at the four different sites on the catalyst surface, NH3 is more inclined to undergo dehydrogenation at the Fe sites. This suggests that the Fe sites on the catalyst surface are more conducive than the Mn sites to facilitate the transformation of NH3 into NH2 species. Additionally, the catalyst surface retains a significant amount of NH2, NH, and other species, which is beneficial for subsequent deNOx reactions. 3.5 The formation of the key NH2NO intermediate According to previous studies [76,77], the generation pathway of the NH2NO intermediate primarily follows two main routes, based on the Eley-Rideal mechanism (E-R mechanism) and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism (L-H mechanism). However, in the end, the generation process of the NH2NO intermediate under both of the pathways is an indispensable step in the deNOx reaction. It plays a vital role in converting NOx into N2 and H2O. Zhou et al. [78] discovered that the formation of the vital NH2NO intermediate is apt to adhere to the E-R mechanism. Hence, in this study, the NH2NO intermediate is formed via the E-R pathway. After the completion of the NH3 dehydrogenation process, adsorbed NH2 species on the catalyst surface readily combine withNO, forming the NH2NO intermediate. The results of the formation of NH2NO intermediate through the combination of NO with adsorbed NH2 on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface are illustrated in Fig. 7 . To clearly identify the N atoms within each species, the N atom in NH2 at the Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites is named NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5, respectively, and the N atom in gaseous NO molecule is named NO. From Fig. 7, it can be observed that NO binds to the NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 sites, forming NO NFe1, NO NFe2, NO NMn4, and NO NMn5 bonds with bond lengths of 1.868, 1.380, 1.310, and 1.332 Å, respectively. The NO NMn4 bond has the shortest length, indicating that NO has strong bonding ability at the Mn4 site. To further understand their adsorption behavior, E a d s and Δ Q were also calculated, as depicted in Fig. 7. The E a d s of NO on the NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 sites are −1.186, −1.375, −1.962, and −1.570 eV, respectively. Comparing their E a d s values, it is found that the adsorption energy of NO is the smallest on the NMn4 site, suggesting a preference for NO molecules to adsorb and bond on the NMn4 site of the catalyst surface. In addition, the Δ Q value for NO at the NMn4 site amounts to 0.239 e, significantly exceeding the electron transfer quantities observed at the NMn5, NFe2, and NFe1 sites (0.239 > 0.196 > 0.132 > 0.042 e). This suggests that NO gains electrons, and there is a robust interaction between NH2 and NO over the Mn4 site, validating the conclusion that NO prefers to adsorb on the NMn4 site on the catalyst surface. To clearly demonstrate the electrical charge of the NO molecule on the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110), the charge density difference was also calculated, and the findings are presented in Fig. S7. There are large amounts of yellow clouds near the NO molecule, and a significant quantity of cyan clouds gather in proximity to the NH2 species. indicating that electrons transfer from the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) to the NO molecule. The area of yellow clouds around the NO molecule at the NMn4 site is slightly larger than that at other sites, which is consistent with the Bader charge calculation results. To further investigate the binding strength of NO molecules with NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 sites on the catalyst surface, PDOS and COHP calculations were also performed, and the findings are illustrated in Fig. 8 . Upon examination of Fig. 8 (a, c, e, g), it becomes evident that prior to the adsorption of the NO molecule, there is minimal overlap between the p orbitals of the NO atom and those of the NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 atoms, suggestive of a lack of substantial interaction among them. However, the PDOS results shown in Fig. 8 (b, d, f, h) indicate the opposite situation after NO adsorption, suggesting a strong orbital interaction between them. Moreover, the adsorption of NO on the catalyst surface is characterized as chemical adsorption. The COHP analysis of the -COHP diagram after the adsorption of NO on the NFe1 site reveals the presence of numerous strong hybridization peaks around −17.5, −12, and −8 eV. This indicates that the electron pairs here significantly promote the NNFe1 bond formation to the greatest extent. Additionally, there are small hybridization peaks around −2 eV. This suggests that only a very small number of electron pairs inhibit the binding of the NNFe1 bond. The COHP plots at the NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 sites reveal that the newly generated hybridization peaks near −20 eV have the largest absolute y-axis values, implying that a large number of electron pairs converge here and promote the bonding of NNFe2, NNMn4, and NNMn5. Moreover, only a small fraction of electron pairs contributes to the antibonding orbitals, indicating a strong adsorption of NO on the NFe1, NFe2, NMn4, and NMn5 sites on the catalyst surface. By analyzing the magnitudes of the ICOHP values in the COHP plots at the NFe1, NFe2, NMn5, and NMn4 sites (−3.093 > −11,804 > −12.687 > −13.630), it is found that the ICOHP value for the interaction of NO with NMn4 site is the smallest at −13.630. This indicates that the formed NNMn4 bond has the strongest strength. This is also one of the reasons that NO adsorption on the NMn4 site of the catalyst surface exhibits the maximum adsorption energy. 3.6 The route of dissociation of NH2NO intermediate to generate N2 The transformation of the NH2NO intermediate into N2 and H2O involves numerous isomerization and hydrogen migration stages. Fig. 9 depicts the reaction route of the NH2NO on the Fe1 site. The NH2NO undergoes two distinct transformation directions: (1) NH2NO dehydrogenation reaction (*NH2NO + Oβ → *NHNO + OβH) and the entire dehydrogenation process is aided by Oβ present on the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110). (2) Hydrogen atom migration within the NH2NO to the oxygen end (*NH2NO → *NHNOH). In the depiction of the decomposition reaction pathway, E represents the electronic energy of a particular system, E B denotes the reaction barrier, with its value excluding the zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE) at 0 K, and ΔE represents the electronic energy change for a given reaction. From Fig. 9, it can be seen that the overcome E B during the process (a → b) is 3.123 eV, and the entire process releases an energy of 1.148 eV. During the process (a → d), the E B to be overcome is 2.809 eV, and the entire process absorbs an energy of 0.329 eV. Comparing the two processes of a → b and a → d (3.123 > 2.809), hydrogen atoms show a preference for internal migration, transferring to the oxygen end of the NH2NO. The process of b → c, which involves the dehydrogenation of the NHNO, overcomes an E B of 2.183 eV, and the process releases an energy of 2.762 eV. The process a → b → c corresponds to the Fe transformation direction of the NH2NO group (1). The pathways d → f and d → e illustrates the reaction route *NHNOH + *H → *N2 + *H + H2O. During the d → e process, the hydrogen atom undergoes internal migration within the NHNOH, shifting towards the oxygen terminus and forming N2 and H2O. The E B of this process is 2.409 eV and the energy released is 2.378 eV. The d → f entails the -OH internal migration in the NHNOH group towards the hydrogen terminus, producing N2 and H2O. The E B of this process is 2.814 eV and the energy released is 3.084 eV. It is evident that the d → e process is more probable to occur than that of the d → f process, suggesting that the detachment of the H atom from the NHNOH is more likely than that of the -OH group, resulting in internal migration and the formation of H2O and N2. In essence, the most preferential route for NH2NO to produce N2 is *NH2NO + *H → *NHNOH + *H → *N2 + *H + H2O. Consequently, under certain circumstances, the intermediate NH2NO can transform into N2. Fig. 10 displays the decomposition mechanism of the NH2NO intermediate located at the Fe2 site on the catalyst surface. The E B for the dehydrogenation process of a → b is 1.549 eV, and the energy released is 1.384 eV. However, the E B for the process of the H internal migration from the NH2NO to the O terminus (a → d) is 1.999 eV, and it absorbs an energy of 1.259 eV. Simultaneously, the E B for the process of the H internal migration in the NHNO (b → c) is 2.170 eV, with an energy release of 1.289 eV, leading to the formation of N2 and H2O. Therefore, it can be summarized that on the Fe2 site of the catalyst surface, the NH2NO group is more predisposed towards undergoing dehydrogenation reactions. Compared the E B values for the a → b in Figs. 9 and 10 ( E B =3.123 eV > E B =1.549 eV), as well as the E B values of the a → e in Figs. 9 and 10 ( E B =2.809 eV > E B =1.999 eV), it can be inferred that the NH2NO group is more prone to decomposition on the Fe2 site. The d → e and d → f pathways illustrate the *NHNOH + *H → *N2 + *H + H2O reaction route. The process of d → e occurs the H internal migration, with an E B of 1.826 eV and an energy release of 3.444 eV. On the other hand, d → f represents the internal migration of -OH to the H terminus, with an E B of 0.384 eV and an energy release of 1.847 eV. Comparing the E B values for these two processes, it can be concluded that the d → f process ( E B =0.384 eV) is more favorable than the d → e process ( E B =1.826 eV). This suggests that the detachment of the -OH group in the NHNOH group on the Fe2 site is more probable than the detachment of the hydrogen atom, resulting in the generation of N2 and H2O. Fig. 11 depicts the breakdown trajectory of the NH2NO intermediate situated on the Mn4 site of the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. The E B for the dehydrogenation reaction process of a → b is 0.446 eV, with an absorbed energy of 0.259 eV. The E B for the process of b → c is 0.962 eV, with an energy release of 2.974 eV. The consecutive process of a → b → c signifies the dehydrogenation of the NH2NO intermediate, forming N2. The process of a → d occurs the H internal migration to the O terminus, with an E B of 1.727 eV and an absorbed energy of 0.745 eV. Comparing the E B values of the a → b and a → d, the NH2NO on the Mn4 site of the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface is more inclined towards dehydrogenation decomposition. As a result, the preferred route for the NH2NO intermediate on the Mn4 site to efficiently produce N2 is *H + *NH2NO → *2H + *NHNO → *2H + *OH + *N2. The processes of d → e and d → f correspond to the H and -OH internal migration in the NHNOH, respectively. The E B for the d → e is 5.330 eV, and it releases an energy of 2.848 eV. In contrast, the E B for the process of d → f is 0.022 eV, and it releases an energy of 2.558 eV. By comparing the E B values of both processes, it is obtained that the -OH group in the NHNOH intermediate is easier to detachment and internal migration compared to the H atom. Additionally, comparing the E B values for the a → b process in Figs. 10 and 11 ( E B =1.549 eV > E B =0.446 eV), as well as the a → d process in Figs. 10 and 11 ( E B =1.999 eV > E B =1.727 eV), suggests that the NH2NO intermediate is more likely to undergo dissociation and form N2 on the Mn4 site of the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110). Fig. 12 is the dismantling route of the NH2NO intermediate residing on the Mn5 site. The E B for the dehydrogenation process a → b is 2.834 eV, and the absorbed energy is 0.302 eV. However, the process of H internal migration from the NH2NO to the O terminus (a → d) has an E B of 0.986 eV. Simultaneously, the process of H internal migration in the NHNO (b → c) has an E B of 2.876 eV, which forms N2 and H2O. Therefore, it can be concluded that on the Mn5 site, the NH2NO group is more inclined to undergo internal migration reactions of hydrogen atoms. Comparing the E B values for the a → b in Fig. 10 and the a → d in Fig. 12 ( E B =1.549 eV > E B =0.986 eV), as well as the a → d in Figs. 9 and 12 ( E B =2.809 eV > E B =0.986 eV), it can be inferred that the NH2NO group is more likely to undergo decomposition on the Mn5 site of the surface of Fe2O3/MnO2 (110). The d → e and d → f pathways illustrate the *NHNOH + *H → *N2 + *H + H2O reaction route. The process of d → e occurs the H internal migration in the NHNOH, with an E B of 0.719 eV and an energy release of 3.414 eV. The process of d → f represents the -OH internal migration in the NHNOH to the H terminus, with an E B of 0.350 eV and an energy release of 3.575 eV. Comparing the E B values for both processes, it can be concluded that the d → f process ( E B =0.350 eV) is more favorable than the d → e process ( E B =0.719 eV). This suggests that the detachment of the -OH in the NHNOH on the Mn5 site is more probable than the detachment of the hydrogen atom, leading to the formation of N2 and H2O. In summary, the NH2NO intermediate exhibits a tendency towards undergoing internal migration and decomposition processes, leading to the formation of N2 on both the Fe1 and Mn5 sites of the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. Furthermore, the Mn5 site exhibits a more pronounced promotion effect on the decomposition of the NH2NO compared to the Fe1 site. However, at the Fe2 and Mn4 sites, the NH2NO intermediate has a greater proclivity towards dehydrogenation reactions, resulting in the production of N2. Additionally, the Mn4 site shows a more favorable effect on the decomposition of the NH2NO compared to the Fe2 site. Moreover, it is observed that on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface, the NHNOH group located at the Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites demonstrates a greater susceptibility to the detachment of -OH and its internal migration towards the hydrogen terminus, ultimately facilitating the production of N2 and H2O. On the other hand, at the Fe1 site, the NHNOH group has a higher tendency to experience detachment of hydrogen atoms and migrate internally towards the oxygen terminus, leading to the production of N2 and H2O. From these results, it can be concluded that the Mn sites are more effective in promoting the decomposition of the NH2NO intermediate to form N2 compared to the Fe sites. The N2 selectivity, as one of the criteria for evaluating the catalytic performance of catalysts, can be enhanced in manganese-containing catalysts by increasing the Mn content and exposing more Mn sites. This will provide insights and theoretical basis for future research. 4 Conclusions Iron-manganese ore catalysts were prepared and the deNOx tests were conducted to obtain its deNOx performance. In addition, the deNOx mechanism was studied by the DFT method. The adsorption of NH3 over the catalyst surface during the NH3-SCR were systematically investigated. Simultaneously, the N2 selectivity of the catalyst was explored. The primary findings are summarized as follows. (1) 1-Ore contains 35.755 % Mn element and 23.153 % Fe element, with a ratio close to 2:1. Its NOx conversion remains above 85 %, reaching over 98 % even at 120–180 °C. However, its N2 selectivity only is above 75 %. (2) NH3 molecules can stably chemically adsorb at the Fe1, Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites on the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. Upon NH3 adsorption, the molecules lose electrons and transfer towards the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. Compared to the Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites on the catalyst surface, NH3 prefers to adsorb more favorably at the Fe1 site, with an E B of 1.504 eV. (3) The ability of the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface to promote dehydrogenation reactions of NH3 is not high. At the Fe1 site on the catalyst surface, the energy barrier for dehydrogenation of NH3 is 1.107 eV, which is lower than that at other sites on the catalyst surface. This is one of the reasons for the lower N2 selectivity of iron-manganese ore catalysts. (4) Gaseous NO molecules preferentially combine with NH2 species at the Mn4 site on the catalyst surface to form a crucial NH2NO intermediate. At the Fe1 and Mn5 sites, the NH2NO intermediate has a tendency to undergo internal migration and disintegrate, which produces N2. However, at the Fe2 and Mn4 sites, the NH2NO intermediate exhibits a greater propensity towards dehydrogenation reactions and forms N2. The NHNOH moieties situated at the Fe2, Mn4, and Mn5 sites exhibit a higher susceptibility to the detachment of -OH groups, subsequently undergoing internal migration towards the H terminus, ultimately producing N2 and H2O. In contrast, at the Fe1 site, the NHNOH groups have a greater tendency towards detachment of H atoms, followed by internal migration to the O terminus, forming N2 and H2O. Furthermore, compared to the Fe sites, the Mn sites demonstrate greater effectiveness in facilitating the decomposition of NH2NO, leading to the formation of N2. coredata.dc:description: Natural iron-manganese ores exhibit a good deNOx activity at low temperatures after a simple treatment, but the reason for its low N2 selectivity requires further in-depth study. This work conducted deNOx performance and characterization tests on iron-manganese ore catalysts. Based on the experimental results, a simplified computational model of the iron-manganese ore catalyst (Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface) was constructed, and the density functional theory (DFT) method was used to investigate the mechanism of N2 formation in the NH3-SCR process. Fe and Mn in the iron-manganese ore play an important role in the deNOx activity, and NH3 forms the stable chemical adsorption on its surface, especially on the Fe site, where the adsorption capacity of NH3 is stronger than that of Mn site. The Fe site exhibits better ability than the Mn site in the dehydrogenation reaction of NH3. However, in a comprehensive comparison, the capability of iron-manganese ore catalyst to promote NH3 dehydrogenation is not high. In addition, the key NH2NO intermediate prefers to form on the Mn site over the Fe2O3/MnO2 (110) surface. Among them, the Mn site is better than the Fe site in promoting the decomposition of NH2NO intermediate to form N2. The study can further understand the microscopic mechanism of iron-manganese ore catalysts in N2 formation, which lays a foundation for improving the N2 selectivity of iron-manganese ore deNOx catalysts.
